 All common hunting firearms were at one time or another based on the common design of former military rifles. Single shots have been in service since the very beginning of the American military, either in flint, percussion of metallic cartridge configuration. The lever action, while never officially adopted, was used widely by scouts since the 1860s. The bolt action was adopted as the military rifle of the 1890s and remained that way for many decades, when finally replaced by the semi-automatic in the 1930s.
 
 Every firearm used for hunting and regarded as a "hunting gun" has had its ties with military weapons development.

Are there legal limits on the caliber of weapon one can use to hunt a particular class of game?

 
 Every state sets its own rules and guidelines about allowable caliber, but most generally focus on the minimum allowed caliber for hunting.
 
 In Kansas when it comes to deer hunting, for example, the minimum allowed calibers are:
 
 Rifle: .24"
 Handgun: .24"
 Shotgun: 20 gauge slug
 Muzzleloading rifle: .39"
 Muzzleloading pistol: .45"
 
 Rules like this mean that someone could take their basic AR-15 rifle, replace the upper assembly with a brand new one chambered for the 6.8 Remington SPC, .450 Bushmaster, .50 Beowulf, or .458 SOCOM, replace the 20 or 30 round magazine with a five round magazine, mount a scope on the upper assembly, and it's now suited for hunting even if it doesn't look like it.
